rdf:Description.dc:title: Estimation: A brief survey
rdf:Description.prism:copyright: Copyright © unknown. Published by Elsevier Inc.

dp:document-properties.dp:raw-text:
This special issue is dedicated to Professor Norbert Wiener
whose work on estimation dominated the period 1945-1960 and to Professor R. E. Kalman whose work has been predominate from 1960 to the present
INFORMATION SCIENCES 7,191-202 (1974) 191
Estimation: A Brief Survey
DEMETR10S G. LAINIOTIS
Department of Electrical Engineering, State University of New York at Buffalo, Buffalo, New York 14214
Estimation is a discipline of great theoretical significance and elegance, as well as and, perhaps more importantly, it is an area of wide applicability to a variety of scientific and engineering problems. Indeed, the very origins of estimation are due to the work of Gauss [ 1 ] and Legendre [2], stimulated by astronomical studies. Since then, estimation has been applied successfully to numerous engi- neering problems [3], such as to aerospace problems, e.g. navigation, guidance, tracking and positioning [3-8], electric power systems [3,9-12], process con- trol [13-15], nuclear reactors [16-18], communications [19-22], econometrics [23-26], biomédical systems [27-29], meteorology [30-32], pattern recogni- tion [33-35], seismology [36-39], speech processing [40-41], statistical me- chanics [41a] and many others.
Moreover, estimation not only provides useful solutions to practical engineer- ing problems but it also has intimate connections to a large number of other dis- ciplines, both statistical as well as deterministic [42]. The close connection be- tween estimation and communications in general has already been noted [19- 22]. This interrelationship is especially strong in detection [22,43-44], Karhunen-Loeve expansion of random processes [45-46], and related matters [47]. There exists also a very strong connection between stochastic control and estimation [48-51] ; in fact, this is in the strong form of duality [52-53] which is both theoretically appealing as well as, and most importantly, practically use- ful from a realization or computational standpoint. There are numerous other disciplines closely related to estimation, ranging from information theory and coding to functional analysis [42]. Specifically, estimation impinges on infor- mation theory and coding, and vice-versa [54-57], e.g. the calculation of mutual information [55, 55 a], application of information-theoretic criteria to estima- tion [54-56], and decoding algorithms such as the Berlecamp-Massey algorithm for decoding BCH codes [57]. It also has close connections to the solution of integral equations [58-60], and to two-point boundary value problems, as well as to problems associated with state-variable realization of systems from impulse response or transfer-function data, and the inversion of multivariable linear sys- tems [61]. Applications have been found to problems of network theory and stability theory, such as polynomial factorization [62]. Estimation also has in-
© American Eisevier Publishing Company, Inc., 1974
192 DEMETRIOS G. LAINIOTIS
tegral theoretical connections with Hubert-space theory, operator theory, and more generally with functional analysis [63-64].
Since the work of Gauss [1] in 1795, estimation has attracted considerable attention by mathematicians, scientists and engineers, resulting in an enormous literature. This has been especially true in the last four decades. Past efforts were directed both to the derivation of theoretical results pertaining to the rele- vant probability densities (information representation part of the estimation problem) and to estimates (realization part of the problem), as well as, and most frequently, to the derivation of computationally efficient or even approximate, but realizable, estimators. Following Gauss' and Legendre's pioneering work, relatively little appeared until Fisher introduced his maximum likelihood ap- proach [65] in 1912, which has been thoroughly investigated, mainly by statis- ticians [66]. By the late 30's, the theory of probability and stochastic processes had, following Kolmogorov's work [67], matured to the point where estimation problems could be viewed and formulated from a new standpoint. Wold's Ph.D. thesis on discrete stationary processes [68] was the first to use this new view- point, introducing several significant new results, such as the decomposition of regular random processes. Kolmogorov's [69] definitive work on linear mean- square-error (mse) prediction of stationary, discrete random processes, followed Wold's fundamental decomposition approach. Independently of Kolmogorov and following a different approach, Wiener [69] considered and solved the problem of continuous, linear, mse-filtering and prediction of stationary random processes. Wiener's formulation utilized modeling of random processes in terms of correlation functions or spectral densities resulting in the necessity for solving Wiener-Hopf integral equations in order to realize the estimators. While Kolmogorov's approach was mainly mathematical, Wiener's was motivated by practical applications such as fire control, communications, weather forecasting, etc. Moreover, Wiener was interested not only in theoretical results but in their realization as well. As such, Wiener's work dominated the literature in the pe- riod 1940-1960.
Wiener's fundamental work was extended and generalized in the late 40's and in the 50's. Both time and frequency domain techniques were used with the lat- ter being predominant. Special results and techniques were obtained to partially solve the finite observation interval problem and the estimation of nonstationary processes. Most noteworthy contributions are those ofZadeh and Ragazzini [70], Bode and Shannon [71], Shinbrot [72], Yaglom [73], and Helstrom [74]. The results of Zadeh-Ragazzini [70] and Bode-Shannon [71] are particularly noteworthy because of the use of an innovations or "shaping filter" approach. Extensions to discrete-time problems were made by Franklin [75] and Lees [76]. As far as the nonstationary random process estimation problem using time-domain techniques is concerned, the following contributions are also note- worthy: Carlton and Follin [77], Pugachev [78], Swerling [4], Bucy [79], and
ESTIMATION: A SURVEY 193
Parzen [80-81]. Carlton and Follin's and Swerling's results are especially note- worthy for their pioneering of the sequential, unbiased estimation viewpoint and for their emphasis on computational efficiency.
The concern for computational efficiency also dominated the work of a group of researchers, mainly from MIT, that followed a different approach from the above researchers, although they also worked in the time-domain. Most noteworthy of these are: Levinson [1-73], who obtained an efficient recursive implementation of the discrete Wiener filter, followed by Durbin [82], who in- dependently rediscovered Levinson's results, and Whittle [83] who extended them to multivariate time-series. Levinson's work has had its greatest impact to date in geophysics, his results having been extensively used and significantly ex- tended by several workers, such as Robinson, Treitel, and others [36-38]. The recursive algorithms they obtained are closely related to the theory of orthog- onal polynomials [42].
Following Wiener's fundamental contributions which dominated the period 1940-1960, Kalman's [II-l, 3]1 contributions are the most significant. Indeed, Kalman's work dominated the literature in the period 1960-1974, as well as con- tributed appreciably to the practical solution of engineering problems, especially in the aerospace field. Specifically, Kalman [II-l, 3] provided a sequential and computationally efficient solution of the discrete linear filtering and prediction problems, while Kalman and Bucy [11-2] similarly solved the continuous ones. Kalman and Bucy [II-l, 2, 3] utilized a state-space formulation of the problem to obtain their elegant, theoretically significant, computationally efficient, and useful algorithms, and also, and perhaps more importantly, to obtain the techni- cal conditions, namely, controllability and observability, for which the optimum filter is stable or robust.
Following Kalman's and Kalman and Bucy's state-space pioneering work, there ensued an incredible volume of technical papers obtaining essentially the same algorithms, each using a different approach or considering different aspects of the problem. These are due to: Ho [11-5], using a stochastic approximation approach, Ho and Lee [11-6] using a Bayesian approach, Rauch et al. [11-7], using a max. likelihood approach, Athans and Tse [11-8] using the maximum principle, Kailath [11-10] using the innovations, and Meditch [II-l 1] utilizing projections. Most recently, Moifetal. [1-71], and Kailath [11-12] derived a computationally efficient algorithm for obtaining the Kalman filter gains for constant linear systems, using essentially the Abarzumian-Chandrasekhar [11-46] solution to the Riccati equation. This algorithm is related to the Levinson algo- rithm [1-73] for discrete processes.
Similarly, the state-variable formulation of the linear smoothing problem has
'See D. G. Lainiotis, "Partitioned Estimation Algorithms, 11: Linear Estimation," this issue, for these references.
194 DEMETRIOS G. LAINIOTIS
attracted an even greater attention. Specifically, it has been solved by Bryson and Frazier [11-13], Rauch [11-14], Lee [11-15], Cox [11-16], Mayne [11-17], Fraser [11-18], Meditch [II-19-21], Bryson and Henrikson [11-22], Baggeroer [11-24], Kailath and Frost [11-25], Kwakernaak [11-26], Zachrisson [11-27], Andersen et al. [11-30, 31], and others.
In a radically different approach to the linear estimation problem, Lainiotis [11-36, 37], using the "Partition theorem," obtained fundamentally new linear filtering, prediction and smoothing algorithms for continuous and discrete data m terms of explicit, integral expressions of a "partitioned" nature given through decoupled forward filters. The "partitioned" algorithms are especially advanta- geous from an analysis as well as from a computational standpoint. Specifically, the "partitioned" algorithms yield further insight as well as several new results [81a, 81b] on: a) unbiased estimation; b) filter initialization procedures; c) re- processed smoothing [11-37] ; d) stochastic observability and controllability; e) the interconnection between stochastic observability, Fisher information matrix, and the Cramer-Rao bound; f) estimation error-bounds; and most importantly g) computationally effective "partitioned" solutions of time-varying matrix Riccati equations. The "partitioned" solutions serve as the basis of numerically superior computational algorithms for the solution of Riccati as well as of Fredholm integral equations [11-50]. It must be noted that all of the above re- sults were obtained [81b, 11-36, 37, 50, 53] for general, time-varying lumped lin- ear systems. Moreover, it has been shown that all previously established linear filtering and smoothing algorithms can be readily obtained from the "parti- tioned" algorithms. In fact, the "partitioned" filtering algorithms constitute generalizations to time-varying models of the so-called Chandrasekhar- Abarzumian linear estimation algorithms for constant models obtained by Kailath [I-70]2, Moïfetal. [1-71], and Sidhu and Kailath [1-72]. Moreover, ïAorfetal. [1-71], and Sidhu and Kailath [1-72] have obtained the Chandrasekhar-Abarzumian algorithms for constant, discrete and continuous models by using Lainiotis' "partitioning" approach [1-30,40,43, 46, 50, 56,83] which yields important shift-invariance properties for the time-invariant case.
While the linear estimation problem continued to receive immense attention during the 50's and 60's, interest in nonlinear estimation kept rising, due to its theoretical importance and, most importantly, dictated by the need for more sophisticated estimation procedures with which to solve practical engineering problems. Specifically, the use of linear estimation procedures where the basic underlying physical models were nonlinear led to unsatisfactory results, such as divergence. Several attempts were made to alleviate divergence and related diffi- culties with some success, by Jazwinski [1-35], Sorenson [1-59], Fitzgerald
See D. G. Lainiotis, "Partitioned Estimation Algorithms, I: Nonlinear Estimation," this issue, for these references.
ESTIMATION: A SURVEY 195
[88], Athans [89] and many others. However, the basic need to consider opti- mal nonlinear estimation remained and the subject received and continues to re- ceive considerable attention.
There exist two fundamental approaches to nonlinear estimation, in fact, to estimation in general [1-33], namely, the variational or least-squares approach (sometimes also called statistical) and the probabilistic or bayesian viewpoint. Research efforts are directed both to the derivation of exact results pertaining to the relevant a-posteriori probabilities and mean-square estimates [1-1-14, 17-19, 24-26, 30-32, 38-43,46,49-50, 54-56, 58, 62] as well as, and most fre- quently, to the derivation of approximate but realizable nonlinear estimators [1-15, 16, 18-23, 27-30, 33, 35-38,40, 43-48, 50, 53-55, 59-61].
Nonlinear filtering research in the 1950's was stimulated to a great extent by Wiener's work [69]. Wiener's results required for their implementation the so- called nonlinear Wiener Kernels whose determination and realization are very hard. Subsequently, following the bayesian approach and using a dynamical modeling of the pertinent continuous random processes, Stratonovich [1-1, 2], and Kushner [1-4, 5, 13, 16], obtained partial differential equations for the time-evolution of the a-posteriori probabilities and the mean-square estimates. Related contributions were also made later by Wonhan [1-7], and especially Fisher and Stear [1-17,36]. Mortensen [1-11,24] and Duncan [1-14] made contributions in the rigorous establishment of the above results and Ho and Lee [1-6,11-15] considered the discrete nonlinear estimation problem. Later, Frost and Kailath [1-19,42], using the innovations approach considered a larger class of problems and obtained integral representations of the exact nonlinear estima- tors as well as approximate realizations in terms of orthogonal series.
The variational approach to the nonlinear estimation problem received also some attention, the most noteworthy contributions being those of Bryson and Frazier [II-13], Bellman, et al. [90], Detchmendy and Stridhar [1-12], and Cox [11-6], the latter considering the discrete case.
In the 1960's, while most of the attention was focused on the general non- linear estimation problem, considerable attention was also paid to the adaptive estimation problem, namely, to the special class of nonlinear estimation prob- lems with linear models and time-invariant random parameters. This interest was spurred on by the desire to render the Kaiman filter applicable to a more general class of physical problems for which the models were not completely known a-priori. Of the early contributions most noteworthy are those of Rauch [91], Fralick [92], Magill [1-9], Lainiotis [1-22, 23, 30], and Lainiotis and Hilborn [1-18, 25, 31], all of whom dealt with the discrete case. The more difficult continuous case was completely solved by Lainiotis [1-30, 38,40,46, 50], who obtained exact integral expressions for the a-posteriori probabilities, the mean- square estimates, and the corresponding error-covariance matrix for filtering, prediction, and smoothing. The results given m the "partition theorem" were in
196 DEMETRIOS G. LA1NIOTIS
a form which is amenable both to interpretation as well as to effective approxi- mate realization. Lainiotis' results were subsequently applied to other special classes of nonlinear estimation problems, such as detection [1-38, 40, 46, 50], and estimation with nongaussian initial state but linear models [1-40, 43]. The results of the "partition theorem" are particularly noteworthy in several impor- tant respects: a) they give the nonlinear estimators in a "partitioned" form, namely, in terms of a set of decoupled linear Kalman filters, which is amenable to parallel processing realization. This is in marked contrast to previous realiza- tions of the nonlinear estimator in terms of a set of coupled partial differential equations, all of which contain the observations and whose implementation is not easily forthcoming or the effect of approximations easily assessed; and b) they provide error-covariance matrix expressions in an integral "partitioned" form which is both illuminating as well as readily realizable with a minimum of addi- tional computational effort. It must be noted that this exact error-covariance expression is the only one in nonlinear estimation to date.
In the mid-sixties, a different formulation of the general nonlinear estimation problem was introduced by Bucy [1-8] that was based on function-space consid- erations. Specifically, Bucy, using the function-space approach obtained a gen- eralized Bayes' rule for the a-posteriori probability, namely the so-called Bucy "representation theorem." The most general form of this was subsequently given by Kallianpur and Striebel [1-39]. It must be noted, however, that in the form given, Bucy's representation theorem could not be evaluated or even readily used. Following his adaptive or "partitioning" approach to nonlinear es- timation problems, Lainiotis [1-43] obtained a "partitioned" representation (a-posteriori probability) which is an explicit Bayes rule amenable to interpreta- tion and ready use. This general "partition" theorem is the natural generaliza- tion of Lainiotis' "partition" theorem for adaptive estimation. Using the "parti- tion" theorem the nonlinear estimation problem is treated [II] from a global viewpoint that readily yields and unifies previously derived and seemingly un- related results, as well as yielding fundamentally new estimation algorithms, in terms of explicit, integral expressions in a "partitioned" or parallel realization form. Independently, Lo [1-49] and later Dunn and Rhodes [1-58] obtained similar representation theorems, for similar estimation problems.
While the theoretical aspects of the nonlinear problem attracted considerable attention, even greater attention was paid to the realization aspects of the prob- lem [1-15,16,18-23,27-30,33,35-38,40,43-48,50,53-55,59-61,81]. In the approximate realization of nonlinear estimators two fundamentally distinct methods were taken, namely the "local" approach [1-59], as exemplified by the extended Kalman filter, and the "global" approach [1-59], as exemplified by the quantization approach of Fralick [92], Magill [1-9], Lainiotis [1-18, 22-23, 25, 27, 30, 38, 40,46, 50, 51, 55], Bucy [1-29], and the gaussian sum approach of Aoki [1-15], Sorenson and Alspach [1-45, 53, 59, 61], Lainiotis [1-23, 41,43,
ESTIMATION: A SURVEY 197
50, 52, 55], and Lo [1-28, 49, 54]. Other "global" approximations are based on splines, e.g., Wahba and Kimeldorf [93], deFiguerido and Jan [1-47], Wienert and Kailath [94], Lainiotis and Deshpande [1-60], as well as on more general least-square approximations such as those proposed by Lainiotis [1-22, 22], Frost [1-19], Center [144], Alengrin [95], Leondes, et al. [96], and oth- ers [97-98]. Some interest was also shown in establishing exact expressions or at least bounds for the evaluation of the performance of nonlinear estimators. In this regard, noteworthy are the contributions of Zakai and Ziv [99], Snyder and Rhodes [100], and especially Gilman and Rhodes [101-102], all of whom ob- tained estimation-error-bounds, as well as the exact, "partitioned," and integral error-covariance expressions of Lainiotis [1-40, 43, 46, 50].
The field of estimation is a particularly rich and robust field that continues to attract the attention of scientists, mathematicians, and engineers in the 1970's. The current trends of the field consist of significant extensions in the generality and richness of the models considered, e.g., doubly stochastic models considered by Snyder [103-104], Frost [105], Segal [106], Bremand [107], and Van Schuppen [108], rotational process models recently pursued by Willsky and Lo [109-110], distributed process models considered by Balakrishnan and Lions [111], Tzafestas and Nightingale [112], Kushner [l 13], Meditch [l 14], Yu, Seinfeld and Ray [l 15], delay models investigated by Kwakernaak [116] and Koivo [117], and other models proposed by Parzen [118-119]. Other trends consist of broadening of the class of cost functionals used, e.g., information- theoretic cost functionals, etc., as considered by Wiedeman and Stear [120], Akaike [121], Kashyap [122], and Zaborzsky [123]. Also, the realization and performance evaluation aspects of Nonlinear estimation research will continue to receive considerable attention in the future, especially as they pertain to spe- cific scientific and engineering applications.
